author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Wole Soyinka Is Not Going Anywhere
description: The Nobel laureate, whose new novel, “Chronicles From the Land of the Happiest People on Earth,” is his first in nearly 50 years, refuses to back down when he senses that his homeland’s freedom is under threat.
content: ABEOKUTA, Nigeria — Wole Soyinka the firebrand activist is always getting Wole Soyinka the writer into trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 8 Arrested in Fraternity Pledge’s Alcohol-Poisoning Death, Police Say
description: Adam Oakes, a 19-year-old student at Virginia Commonwealth University, died in February after being told to drink a bottle of Jack Daniel’s whiskey, family members say.
content: Eight people were arrested and three others indicted on Friday after an investigation into the death of Adam Oakes, a student at Virginia Commonwealth University who died in February from alcohol poisoning at a fraternity party, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Katie Benner
title: To Get Back Arrested Executive, China Uses a Hardball Tactic: Seizing Foreigners
description: The speed at which Beijing returned two Canadians held seemingly tit-for-tat in exchange may signal comfort with the tactic.
content: In a rapid-fire climax to a 1,030-day standoff, China welcomed home a company executive whose arrest in Canada and possible extradition to the United States made her a focus of superpower friction. In getting her back, Beijing brandished a formidable political tool: using detained foreign citizens as bargaining chips in disputes with other countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Víctor Manuel Ramos
title: New York weighs using the National Guard to replace unvaccinated health care workers.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has plans to use National Guard members and out-of-state professionals to cover staff shortages if thousands of health care workers fail to meet a state vaccination deadline on Monday.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York is considering calling in the National Guard and recruiting medical professionals from other states to cover looming staff shortages at hospitals and other facilities as the likelihood grows that tens of thousands of health care workers will not meet the state’s deadlines for mandated vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Norway lifts coronavirus restrictions after 561 days.
description: “Now the time has come to return to a normal daily life,” the prime minister, Erna Solberg, said.
content: Norway on Saturday lifted social distancing rules, capacity limits on businesses and other pandemic-era restrictions that have been in place for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: In Reversal, Israel’s New Government Engages With Palestinian Authority
description: The government has held high-level meetings with Palestinian officials and aided the Palestinians economically, a sharp change from the previous government.
content: JERUSALEM — One night last month, a top Israeli minister traveled the winding roads of the occupied West Bank to meet Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Greek Goddess of Memory
description: Adam Simon Levine’s debut puzzle speaks to us, in words we can’t pronounce.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Capping off a week of daily grids from brand- or almost-new constructors is this debut poser from Adam Simon Levine, with a dramatic centerpiece. I really needed the success jingle to know that I’d finished, at which point I unapologetically went to the internet to learn something new. When this happens on a Saturday, I consider the knowledge gained to be value added, especially when it’s something fascinating and important that slipped through the cracks of my experience and education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A 3-D Model Built With Public Records and Phone Calls
description: For an interactive article on business inside the Empire State Building, a New York Times team turned to interviews with tenants, vacancy listings, promotional materials and real estate data.
content: In late May, when the New York Times journalists Keith Collins and Matthew Haag sent their first email to the company that owns the Empire State Building, New York was expected to fully reopen within six to eight weeks — and they had an ambitious idea for how to cover it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Will Lawmakers Finally Act Against Big Tech?
description: Facebook may have crossed the line.
content: Kids and whistle-blowers. This is the heart of the recent Wall Street Journal series of investigations about how Facebook runs its business. And it’s why the articles landed with such force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allen C. Guelzo
title: How Do I Tell the Story of Robert E. Lee?
description: Exposing the complicated truth of America's past is the real work of historians.
content: This month in Virginia, the most famous statue of Robert E. Lee — a 21-foot-tall bronze equestrian sculpture — was swung down from its granite base on Richmond’s Monument Avenue and cut in two at the waist so that it could fit under highway overpasses on its final journey to an undisclosed state facility. Hundreds gathered to cheer the event as a victory for racial justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: A Path to Financial Security That Doesn’t Lead to a 401(k)
description: Some Black and Hispanic millennials are looking to alternatives like real estate or entrepreneurship, or to trading stock on their own.
content: Raul Duplessi became intrigued with the stock market nearly 15 years ago, when he landed his first job as a hotel doorman in Manhattan and a TV near his workstation played financial news on a continuous loop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Anita Hill Has Some Perspective to Offer
description: Thirty years after she testified before the Senate, the law professor talks about the experience, sexual harassment and her growing impatience with the slow pace of change.
content: Anita Hill still speaks in the measured tones she did while being questioned before an all-white, all-male panel before the Senate in 1991 — a young law professor in a blue linen suit who would give the nation an overnight education in workplace sexual harassment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Icelanders Vote in Volatile Election With Climate in Mind
description: Icelanders voted Saturday in a general election dominated by climate change, with an unprecedented number of political parties likely to win parliamentary seats.
content: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Icelanders were voting Saturday in a general election dominated by climate change, with an unprecedented number of political parties likely to win parliamentary seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Angela Merkel Was Underestimated, and It Became Her Superpower
description: Her 16-year reign is evidence that effective politics doesn't require losing your humanity.
content: Almost every article written about Angela Merkel’s tenure as Germany’s chancellor notes that one of her greatest political strengths has been that she is so often underestimated. In this, she is not unique: Helmut Kohl, who launched Ms. Merkel into politics and spent even more time in the chancellor’s office, once declared, “I make my living by being underestimated.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: ‘No Time to Be a Child’
description: During the pandemic, teenage girls took on more caregiving at home, extra shifts at work and the burden of organizing racial justice protests. In many instances, it upended their lives.
content: — A poem by Azariah Baker, a high school student in Chicago
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Democrats’ Spending Fight Carries High Stakes for Their Candidates
description: Failure of moderates and progressives to reach a deal would fuel Republican attacks on their competence — with consequences as soon as November in Virginia, and in the midterms next year.
content: WASHINGTON — With President Biden’s approval ratings falling below 50 percent after the most trying stretch of his young administration, pushing through his ambitious legislative agenda has taken on a new urgency for Democratic lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In America’s Restaurants, Many Are Hosting Till It Hurts.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 25, 2021.
content: “Our manager bought us this air horn to keep at the hostess stand in case somebody does get disruptive or too violent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: A Quarterback Duel Fizzles, but the Irish Explode
description: Jack Coan, who transferred to Notre Dame from Wisconsin, looked more solid than his Badger replacement, though he left the game in the third quarter with an injury.
content: Saturday’s game between Notre Dame and Wisconsin had an air of suspense before the two teams even took the field. Did Wisconsin Coach Paul Chryst make the right decision in sticking with quarterback Graham Mertz over Jack Coan? How would Coan, now Notre Dame’s quarterback, fare against his former team? Would this game add Coan to a growing list of quarterback transfers who elevate their new programs upon arrival?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: This Is No Way to End a Pandemic
description: Getting first shots in arms, globally, is more important than any booster program.
content: A year ago, before any Covid vaccine had been authorized for use, former President Donald Trump all but promised that a shot would be available before Election Day. When Food and Drug Administration regulators suggested that he was mistaken, he accused them of deliberately slow-walking their authorizations in an attempt to influence the coming election — and threatened to override them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Sisson
title: One Solution to a Shortage of Skilled Workers? Diversify the Construction Industry.
description: President Biden’s infrastructure plan would create a hiring challenge, but also an opportunity to recruit from communities that the industry has long ignored.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: What Is CoolSculpting?
description: The fat-freezing procedure left supermodel Linda Evangelista “disfigured.” Here’s what experts say it is supposed to do and what the most common side effects are.
content: On Wednesday, Linda Evangelista, the ’90s-era supermodel, shared on Instagram that she had been disfigured by a fat-reducing procedure called CoolSculpting that did the opposite of what it promised: Instead of reducing the amount of fat she had, CoolSculpting increased it, she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Two more federal judges rule against the Tennessee governor’s ban on mask mandates.
description: The rulings were the second and third the last two weeks to suspend Gov. Bill Lee’s executive order after parents sued, charging that it violated the Americans with Disabilities Act.
content: Two federal judges in Tennessee have dealt blows to Gov. Bill Lee’s executive order that allows families to opt out of school mask mandates, ruling in separate cases on Friday that local districts could require face coverings to protect disabled children while legal challenges progress through the courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Steven Lee Myers
title: How Record Rain and Officials’ Mistakes Led to Drownings on a Subway
description: The deluge in the city of Zhengzhou revealed how China’s years of go-go construction had left its cities vulnerable to climate change.
content: ZHENGZHOU, China — The heaviest hour of rainfall ever reliably recorded in China crashed like a miles-wide waterfall over the city of Zhengzhou on July 20, killing at least 300 people, including 14 who drowned in a subway tunnel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Payne and James Lynch
title: How to Build Roller Skates
description: The pandemic made roller-skating popular again. For The New York Times for Kids, the photographer Christopher Payne visited Riedell Skates to see how they’re made.
content: Ever since the pandemic forced everyone to find new hobbies, roller-skating has been a hit, with dancers and daredevils going viral on Instagram and TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Music and Cookouts in a Tent City for Afghans Starting Life in the U.S.
description: On a military base in New Jersey, 8,500 people who fled their country as it fell to the Taliban await the next step in their journey.
content: They call it Liberty Village, a tent city that grew almost overnight to have a population larger than half of the towns in New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Oleksandr Usyk Upsets Anthony Joshua to Upend Heavyweight Boxing Picture
description: Usyk beat Joshua in a unanimous decision as Joshua had been openly looking toward the winner of a forthcoming Tyson Fury-Deontay Wilder bout.
content: Anthony Joshua needed a knockout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camila Falquez and Julia Carmel
title: Bushwig Grows Up
description: The annual festival celebrated 10 years of drag, queerness and artistry this month, but some local queens want more.
content: Bushwig, the end-of-summer drag weekend extravaganza held each year in New York, was born of a simple desire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: A federal appeals court delays New York City’s vaccine mandate for teachers.
description: The mandate, which affects well over 150,000 people working in the nation’s largest school system, was set to go into effect on Monday at midnight.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration has been temporarily blocked from enforcing a vaccine mandate for nearly all adults in New York City public school buildings, after a federal appeals court granted a temporary injunction on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Cloyd Boyer, Last of a Three-Brother Baseball Rarity, Dies at 94
description: His pitching career was cut short, but at one time he and his brothers Ken and Clete were all on the major league stage together. He ended up outliving them.
content: Cloyd Boyer pitched for the St. Louis Cardinals and the Kansas City Athletics and, in a baseball career of nearly a half century, later worked as a pitching coach for the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves and as a minor league manager, a roving pitching instructor and a scout.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Affluent, Anxious and Almost Normal: A Journey Through Merkel’s Germany
description: As Germany heads into an election that will see Angela Merkel step down after 16 years as chancellor, she leaves behind a country profoundly changed — and anxious about changing more.
content: STUTTGART, Germany — The small silver star at the tip of Aleksandar Djordjevic’s Mercedes shines bright. He polishes it every week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
title: ‘I Need an Army’: Across America, Schools Cram for Their Covid Tests
description: Some districts have established robust virus testing programs, but many others are struggling.
content: SAN ANTONIO — One recent Thursday, Ciara Brown, a junior at Fox Tech High School in San Antonio, stepped up to a small white table, pulled down her face mask and took a test that is still far from standard in American schools: a cotton swab up the nose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Whales So Close You Can Touch Them: A Family Adventure in Canada
description: Recalling a prepandemic trip to a watery landscape in Quebec province: “The adventure we had feels like one plucked from a world I can no longer reach, not unlike watching the water, waiting for a whale to crest.”
content: The trail to our yurt was narrow, muddy and peppered with tiny ceramic and plastic gnomes, fairies and bears. My 8-year-old daughter, clutching her stuffed giraffe and gingerly avoiding the knotty roots, spotted a miniature tiger, crouched at the base of a pine tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The World Lost a Great Philosopher This Week
description: A tribute to Charles W. Mills.
content: This has been a sad week for those of us who read, study and care about political philosophy. That’s because Charles W. Mills, a U.K.-born and Jamaica-raised philosopher whose life’s work was the interrogation and critique of the foundations of liberalism, died on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Donovan and Muriel Alarcón
title: Long Hours, Low Pay, Loneliness and a Booming Industry
description: The ranks of home health aides are expected to grow more than any other job in the next decade. What kind of work are they being asked to do?
content: For 15 years, Yvette Dessin spent long work days with her elderly patients, accompanying them on walks, cooking them meals and bathing those who needed that most intimate kind of care. If a patient died, Ms. Dessin and her adult daughter attended the funeral services to pay their respects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can You Break the Lease if Your Apartment Might Flood?
description: Maintaining a rental property — including making sure water drains properly — is the responsibility of the landlord, not the tenant.
content: Q: I live in a Park Slope garden apartment with ongoing drainage issues. During hurricanes Henri and Ida, I was bucketing water away from the door, which leads to my bedroom. I bought a raised drain guard and a sump pump that hooks up to a garden hose, but the pump couldn’t keep up. Because I was home, the damage was limited. But what if a big storm hits when I’m not home? The management company told me to deduct the cost of the pump from the rent. But shouldn’t the landlord address the larger drainage issues?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Augugliaro
title: 7 Gadgets to Make You Less Weird When You Go Back to the Office
description: Has returning to your workplace got you down? These inventions can help.
content: After 18 months of isolation, it’s time to dust off your favorite Dockers. We put in 130 hours of research and testing to offer you seven gadgets that will help you ease back into the daily grind. Strap on your lanyard; we’re going in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Reparations for Black Residents Are Becoming a Local Issue as Well as a National One
description: While legislation in Washington remains stalled, state and local governments are breathing new life into the reparations movement.
content: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Day and Samantha Stark
title: The Surveillance Apparatus That Surrounded Britney Spears
description: An account by a former employee of the security team hired by Ms. Spears’s father created the most detailed portrait yet of the singer’s life under 13 years of conservatorship.
content: Britney Spears’s father and the security firm he hired to protect her ran an intense surveillance apparatus that monitored her communications and secretly captured audio recordings from her bedroom, including her interactions and conversations with her boyfriend and children, according to a former employee of the security firm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Robinhood Hits Campus, Where Credit Card Companies Fear to Tread
description: The company plans to hit up college coffee shops to spread the word about its services. When credit card companies did it a generation ago, Congress got involved.
content: Robinhood, the free stock-trading app with 21 million active users and counting, is about to hit the road for a college coffeehouse tour to drum up new customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman
title: Among Those Who Marched Into the Capitol on Jan. 6: An F.B.I. Informant
description: A member of the far-right Proud Boys texted his F.B.I. handler during the assault, but maintained the group had no plan in advance to enter the Capitol and disrupt the election certification.
content: As scores of Proud Boys made their way, chanting and shouting, toward the Capitol on Jan. 6, one member of the far-right group was busy texting a real-time account of the march.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Study Breaks
description: Priyanka Sethy and Matthew Stock put us to the test.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s back-to-school season, no matter how long ago we last went back to school; this grid is a reminder of that, but it’s a fun one. It’s a collaboration between Matthew Stock, who has made two Sunday grids and several daily puzzles for The Times, and Priyanka Sethy, who makes her constructing debut. Ms. Sethy is a bicoastal management consultant, and Mr. Stock works for a math education nonprofit in East St. Louis, Ill.; they met via the Crossword Puzzle Collaboration Directory on Facebook and worked together (from Ms. Sethy’s theme idea) over video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Review: Sounds and Styles Playfully Collide in ‘Only an Octave Apart’
description: This show brings together two convention-inverting artists: the cabaret star Justin Vivian Bond and the opera singer Anthony Roth Costanzo.
content: “Have you ever wondered what it’s like to be normal?” Justin Vivian Bond, the doyenne of downtown cabaret, asks the countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo a few songs into their show, “Only an Octave Apart,” at St. Ann’s Warehouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Woman Charged With Arson in Starting California Wildfire, Officials Say
description: The Fawn fire, which has burned nearly 10,000 acres, was spreading quickly on Friday, a day after the authorities accused a Palo Alto woman of igniting the blaze.
content: A woman from Palo Alto, Calif., was charged with arson in connection with a wildfire that has burned about 9,850 acres and damaged more than 25 buildings in Shasta County, worsening the toll of an already brutal fire season in the state, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Dangles Hopes for Summit and End-of-War Declaration
description: Kim Jong-un’s sister responds to the South Korean leader’s last attempt to put the peace process back on track, but skepticism abounds.
content: SEOUL — ​North Korea would consider holding a summit meeting with South Korea and declaring an official end to the Korean War if the South can restore trust with it, the North’s official news agency reported on Saturday, citing the sister of its leader, Kim Jong-un.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Pfizer boosters are recommended for many Americans, and Alaska faces its worst surge: The week in Covid news.
description: Millions of Americans became eligible for booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine this week, after federal regulators recommended it for people inoculated with that vaccine more than six months ago and who fall into one of three categories:  over 65; having underlying medical conditions; or working that put them at risk for infections.
content: Millions of Americans became eligible for booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine this week, after federal regulators recommended it for people inoculated with that vaccine more than six months ago and who fall into one of three categories:  over 65; having underlying medical conditions; or working that put them at risk for infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Let’s Talk About Sex
description: At Prada and Versace, the clothes made it the main topic of conversation.
content: MILAN — Forget the summer of love; welcome to the season of sex. It has been bubbling up ever since New York Fashion Week began (ever since the naked summer, really). But on Friday it moved to the center of the catwalk conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Tannen
title: In Real Life, Not All Interruptions Are Rude
description: Sometimes people talk over each other and it totally works.
content: Interruption — the offense of stealing the floor when someone else is talking — has become the grand larceny of conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can Joe Biden Recover?
description: Biden can definitely float his way back up. Clawing his way up might be a different story.
content: This was a good week for anyone enthused about relitigating the 2020 election. First there was new evidence, reported in a new book about the Biden family from the Politico writer Ben Schreckinger and in an Insider story on an abortive Libya-related influence operation, suggesting the famous Hunter Biden emails were real and indicating how much Hunter’s influence-peddling depended on proximity to his father. The Twitter and Facebook decisions to censor The New York Post’s election-season version of the Hunter Biden story looked partisan and illiberal at the time; now they look worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Anna Joyce
title: U.K.’s Migrant Boat Dispute Has Eyes Fixed on the Channel
description: The southeastern coast of England is increasingly the focal point of Britain’s migration debate as the government advocates more extreme measures to halt asylum seekers arriving by boat.
content: FOLKESTONE, England — Using high-powered binoculars and a telescope, three volunteers from a humanitarian monitoring group stood on the Kent coast, peering across the English Channel. The looming clock tower of the French town of Calais was visible on this clear morning, but so was the distinctive outline of a small rubber dinghy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: U.S. Ryder Cup Team Seizes Big Lead on a Wild Opening Day
description: The action included some harrowing moments for a couple of golfers, and the gallery included Michael Jordan.
content: HAVEN, Wis. — A snapshot panorama from the first day of the Ryder Cup would start with a crowd of 40,000 — 90 percent of it American fans because of pandemic-related travel restrictions — noisily arriving before sunrise on Friday to roar unabated for 12 hours and through eight matches that concluded in the gloaming. Patriotic costumes were in vogue, though not among the most prominent spectators in the mix: Michael Jordan and Stephen Curry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: China frees 2 jailed Canadians after the U.S. agrees to release a Huawei executive.
description: Two Canadians imprisoned in China since 2018 were free and on their way home, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada announced on Friday night.
content: Two Canadians imprisoned in China since 2018 were free and on their way home, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada announced Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: George Mraz, Consummate Jazz Bassist, Dies at 77
description: For half a century, he was in constant demand, backing big names like Oscar Peterson as well as countless up-and-coming performers.
content: George Mraz, a sought-after jazz bassist whose deft, versatile work anchored the recordings and performances of generations of artists, from Oscar Peterson and Dizzy Gillespie more than 50 years ago to Cyrus Chestnut and Joe Lovano in this century, died on Sept. 16. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia and Jennifer Valentino-DeVries
title: They Investigate Police Killings. Their Record Is Wanting.
description: After the murder of George Floyd, some states looked to independent agencies to examine deaths in police custody. But dozens of cases handled by the Texas Rangers show the approach has flaws.
content: When the Texas Rangers learned that a woman had died in a jail south of Dallas, they put Adam Russell on the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox cooks, and Henry Rathvon is a wraith this week.
content: ACROSTIC — Today we have a passage that preys on those of us who like to rely on the limitations of one- and two-letter words to help us fill in a letter or 10 in an acrostic grid. It sometimes happens that we get a reference to someone’s initials, or a special term that includes a single character, but we can usually rely on “a” and “i” as single words. There are a several exceptions today, and they’re integral to the excerpt’s topic, which is all those vowels that we actually have in the English language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Want a Can’t Miss Productivity Tip? Forget About Being Productive.
description: People and industries measure how productive they are in similar ways. This extended period of remote work for many has revealed how flawed that can be.
content: How productive was your day?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How It Feels to Be Asian in Today’s America
description: Twenty-seven perspectives on fear, pride, identity and belonging.
content: Twenty-seven perspectives on fear, pride, identity and belonging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: True Crime, Keith Morrison and Me
description: The stories may be based in reality, but they portray a fictitious world.
content: “Dateline” started its 30th season on Friday. It’s the longest running series on NBC prime-time and one of the best known true crime programs in America.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 25, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 25, 2021.
content: An obituary on Thursday about the filmmaker, author and actor Melvin Van Peebles misstated the year he graduated from Ohio Wesleyan University. It was 1953, not 1954.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should the U.S. Expand the Social Safety Net?
description: Readers disagree with a guest essay that argued that America cannot afford the $3.5 trillion bill now before Congress.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
